--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

I'll get to the other issues later...but I wanted to respond to this
one quickly...

> 
> Thats how I see speciation, simply as grouping genomes that are 
> compatible so that sexual reproduction (crossover) is far more 
likely to 
> generate good offspring.
> 

While this a nice property of speciation, it is not the most 
important contribution.  What's even more important is that fitness 
sharing in species protects innovation, and that allows  
complexification that otherwise wouldn't occur.  The point is: it 
takes longer to optimize a larger structure, so if you want larger 
structures to get a fair chance of being used, they need to be 
protected so that they can realize their potential.  Otherwise, in 
the short run, they will appear inferior and get bumped out of the 
population.  Fitness sharing provides such protection.

Another useful thing about speciation, as I mentioned in my previous 
post, is that it prevents bloat.  It ensures that small genomes will 
persist as long as they are competitive, since they won't be mixing 
with, and don't have to compete directly for offspring with other 
more complex species.

ken
